quotes.topic_title: What Community Notes is and why it works
quotes.text: Someone on X can see a post. If they think it's misleading, they can propose a note that they think other people might find informative. Other people can then rate that note.
quotes.speaker: Keith Coleman
quotes.context: A simple, repeatable workflow for crowdsourcing context: propose → rate → surface what helps.

quotes.topic_title: What Community Notes is and why it works
quotes.text: We actually look for agreement from people who have disagreed in the past. And what we see is when people actually have that sort of surprising agreement, that's what makes the notes so neutral and accurate and well- written, really, overall.
quotes.speaker: Jay Baxter
quotes.context: A methodology for reducing bias: require cross-faction agreement as the gating mechanism for publishing.

quotes.topic_title: What Community Notes is and why it works
quotes.text: One philosophical thing that's important is that we want all of humanity to participate and sometimes people are surprised by that.
quotes.speaker: Keith Coleman
quotes.context: A counterintuitive participation principle: include everyone (even those you disagree with) to improve signal and legitimacy.

quotes.topic_title: What Community Notes is and why it works
quotes.text: Every post is eligible for notes. We shouldn't exempt Elon. We shouldn't exempt government figures. We should be like everyone... Even advertisers can get notes.
quotes.speaker: Keith Coleman
quotes.context: An operational rule that builds trust: apply the same accountability mechanism universally, without carve-outs.

quotes.topic_title: What Community Notes is and why it works
quotes.text: There have been external studies run by people totally independent of us who have found that if you take a post with or without a Community Note, that actually people's agreement with the core claims in the post does change if they see it with a note versus without.
quotes.speaker: Jay Baxter
quotes.context: A measurable outcome claim: notes don’t just add context—they can shift belief in the underlying claim.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: Community Notes is one of the most impactful and clever and, also, underappreciated products in the world right now.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Highlights a product-evaluation lens: look for high-impact systems that are still underappreciated as potential models to study or invest in.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: We get into the surprising origin story of the product, how the algorithm actually works, how the algorithm emerged out of an internal contest within Twitter, the principles behind Community Notes, and why staying true to them has been so key to its success.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Points to a repeatable methodology: use internal contests to surface strong algorithmic approaches and anchor success in clear principles.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: Also, how it survived four different leaders, including Elon and Jack, and why it's now a big part of the solution to solving misinformation on the internet.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Emphasizes building products resilient to leadership changes by grounding them in durable mechanisms and principles.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: Including recently being adopted by Meta as their main fact-checking tool.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A concrete adoption example signaling the approach has cross-platform credibility and practical applicability at scale.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: If you're building a SaaS app, at some point, your customers will start asking for enterprise features like SAML Authentication and SCIM Provisioning.
quotes.speaker: Host
quotes.context: A practical expectation-setting reminder for SaaS builders to plan for enterprise requirements as customer maturity grows.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Their APIs are easy to understand so that you can ship quickly and get back to building other features.
quotes.speaker: Host
quotes.context: Highlights a prioritization principle: reduce integration complexity to preserve engineering time for core product work.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Warrant's product is based on a groundbreaking authorization system called Zanzibar, which was originally designed for Google to power Google Docs and YouTube.
quotes.speaker: Host
quotes.context: A concrete example of leveraging proven, large-scale authorization models when designing fine-grained access control.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: This enables fast authorization checks at enormous scale while maintaining a flexible model that can be adapted to even the most complex use cases.
quotes.speaker: Host
quotes.context: A useful design target for authorization systems: optimize for both scale and adaptability rather than trading one off entirely.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: It's a drop-in replacement for Auth0 and supports up to 1 million monthly active users for free.
quotes.speaker: Host
quotes.context: A specific benchmark and comparison point practitioners can use when evaluating auth/enterprise feature providers.

quotes.topic_title: Community Notes mechanics and bridging agreement algorithm
quotes.text: And if the note is found helpful by people who normally disagree with each other, indicating that it's probably accurate, it's probably really neutrally-worded, it's probably informative, then it will show to everyone on X.
quotes.speaker: Keith Coleman
quotes.context: Defines the core “bridging agreement” mechanism: visibility is gated by cross-group agreement rather than volume or speed.

quotes.topic_title: Community Notes mechanics and bridging agreement algorithm
quotes.text: I think a key misunderstanding a lot of people have if they haven't really dived into details, they just think that maybe someone can write a note and it appears immediately or we're just taking a majority rules vote of who thinks the note's good.
quotes.speaker: Jay Baxter
quotes.context: Highlights a common but flawed mental model (instant publish or majority vote) that leads to predictable bias in community moderation systems.

quotes.topic_title: Community Notes mechanics and bridging agreement algorithm
quotes.text: I think both of those approaches would probably lead to biased or inaccurate notes.
quotes.speaker: Jay Baxter
quotes.context: Actionable warning for system designers: naive aggregation methods (speed/majority) degrade quality and neutrality.

quotes.topic_title: Community Notes mechanics and bridging agreement algorithm
quotes.text: I think the key thing, really, that we do is we actually look for agreement from people who have disagreed in the past.
quotes.speaker: Jay Baxter
quotes.context: A reusable methodology: measure “surprising agreement” across historically opposed cohorts to improve accuracy and reduce bias.

quotes.topic_title: Community Notes mechanics and bridging agreement algorithm
quotes.text: But it turns out that you can do that with this kind of bridging-based agreement algorithm is what we call it.
quotes.speaker: Jay Baxter
quotes.context: Counterintuitive claim that you can bootstrap a robust, manipulation-resistant system without external ground-truth labels by using bridging agreement.

quotes.topic_title: Examples, context vs fact-checking, and openness
quotes.text: A really classic example is an AI generated image or an out of context image like, "Look what's happening here." But it's actually from five years ago in a different country and a different topic or something-
quotes.speaker: Keith Coleman
quotes.context: Concrete example practitioners can use to understand the core problem Community Notes targets: misleading media via AI or missing context.

quotes.topic_title: Examples, context vs fact-checking, and openness
quotes.text: One distinction that I would make, which maybe can come off as nitpicky but I think is important, is Community Notes adds additional context. It's not fact-checking necessarily, right?
quotes.speaker: Jay Baxter
quotes.context: A key framing shift: positioning the product as context augmentation rather than authoritative fact-checking changes expectations and design goals.

quotes.topic_title: Examples, context vs fact-checking, and openness
quotes.text: We just have the philosophy that users should be able to make up their own minds, right? Like, "Here's extra context, take it or leave it," right?
quotes.speaker: Jay Baxter
quotes.context: Actionable product philosophy for trust systems: provide context and preserve user agency instead of enforcing a single “truth.”

quotes.topic_title: Examples, context vs fact-checking, and openness
quotes.text: But very specifically we were like, "No. We're trying to move away from the idea of curated editorial decisions being made around this. This is supposed to be open to everyone."
quotes.speaker: Keith Coleman
quotes.context: Contrarian stance against expert-led curation, emphasizing openness as a trust and legitimacy mechanism.

quotes.topic_title: Examples, context vs fact-checking, and openness
quotes.text: People are randomly selected and that's important to it feeling fair, feeling open, feeling trustable.
quotes.speaker: Keith Coleman
quotes.context: A practical design lever—random selection—to increase perceived fairness and trust in participatory moderation systems.

quotes.topic_title: Eligibility, contributor onboarding, and earning write access
quotes.text: So every post is eligible for notes and that was, again, another really important principle. It's like, "We shouldn't exempt Elon. We shouldn't exempt government figures. We should..." Everyone, even advertisers, can get notes.
quotes.speaker: Keith Coleman
quotes.context: Establishes the core design principle of universal eligibility—no protected classes—creating an “even playing field” for accountability.

quotes.topic_title: Eligibility, contributor onboarding, and earning write access
quotes.text: For a note to be proposed, the person proposing it has to have earned the ability to write notes. So there is that aspect where you have to earn in to be able to do this.
quotes.speaker: Keith Coleman
quotes.context: Highlights an “earn-in” permissioning model that gates creation rights behind demonstrated contribution quality.

quotes.topic_title: Eligibility, contributor onboarding, and earning write access
quotes.text: And the way you earn that ability is through your ratings by demonstrating the ability to help identify notes that are found helpful to a broad range of people.
quotes.speaker: Keith Coleman
quotes.context: Provides an actionable mechanism: build reputation by reliably recognizing what diverse audiences find helpful, not just your in-group.

quotes.topic_title: Eligibility, contributor onboarding, and earning write access
quotes.text: So basically, if you have an ability to see and know, recognize what's helpful with a lot of people, then you have the ability to start proposing notes.
quotes.speaker: Keith Coleman
quotes.context: Offers a clear mental model: writing access is a reward for cross-audience calibration on “helpfulness.”

quotes.topic_title: Eligibility, contributor onboarding, and earning write access
quotes.text: Yeah. It's not super easy. It takes some effort.
quotes.speaker: Keith Coleman
quotes.context: Counterbalances assumptions about open contribution by emphasizing that meaningful access is intentionally effortful to earn.

quotes.topic_title: Scale metrics, media matching, and notification UX
quotes.text: And over let's say the last year, 2024, we had something like 95,000 notes that were seen about 30 billion times. That's more than double the prior year. Prior year was something like 37K notes seen 14 billion times.
quotes.speaker: Keith Coleman
quotes.context: Concrete scale metrics that quantify growth and reach year-over-year, useful for benchmarking and credibility.

quotes.topic_title: Scale metrics, media matching, and notification UX
quotes.text: So if someone writes a note on an image or a video, like let's say it's AI generated or something like that, that note will automatically be matched to all posts that contain the same image. So you can have a single note matching to thousands of posts.
quotes.speaker: Keith Coleman
quotes.context: A scalable methodology: attach moderation/context to reusable media artifacts so one intervention covers many instances.

quotes.topic_title: Scale metrics, media matching, and notification UX
quotes.text: So pulling the context up so that you have zero clicks that you need to make and keeping it specific is so important.
quotes.speaker: Jay Baxter
quotes.context: Actionable UX principle for trust/safety and info products: reduce friction to zero and keep guidance claim-specific.

quotes.topic_title: Scale metrics, media matching, and notification UX
quotes.text: And so, we send those notifications to try to close that gap.
quotes.speaker: Keith Coleman
quotes.context: A practical tactic for correcting misinformation: re-contact users who engaged earlier to mitigate the time-lag problem.

quotes.topic_title: Scale metrics, media matching, and notification UX
quotes.text: Here, you're getting a ping about it if you've engaged with a post and note shows up.
quotes.speaker: Keith Coleman
quotes.context: Memorable product pattern: targeted “correction pings” outperform traditional, passive corrections in reach and salience.

quotes.topic_title: Thresholds, conservatism, and note quality controls
quotes.text: The threshold is it's 0.4 on this made up scale-
quotes.speaker: Jay Baxter
quotes.context: A concrete data point showing that operational thresholds can be set on an internal scale rather than an intuitive percentage.

quotes.topic_title: Thresholds, conservatism, and note quality controls
quotes.text: But if there is, then a sizable majority of people on both sides would generally need to find the note helpful.
quotes.speaker: Jay Baxter
quotes.context: A practical quality bar/decision rule: require cross-group agreement (not just overall majority) to publish in polarized contexts.

quotes.topic_title: Thresholds, conservatism, and note quality controls
quotes.text: So even if it's above that threshold, it might get filtered out if... There's a separate algorithm that's looking at agreement between people's incorrect tags. So like maybe people found the note helpful but incorrect, right? It happens. And in those cases, it doesn't matter if it's above the helpfulness threshold.
quotes.speaker: Jay Baxter
quotes.context: A methodology for quality control: add secondary “safety” filters so content can be blocked even when primary metrics look good.

quotes.topic_title: Thresholds, conservatism, and note quality controls
quotes.text: We arrived at some numbers like that by gauging user feedback. So we could share a lot of notes with people, get feedback on which ones are helpful, and just a line emerged about indicating where things go from questionable to pretty clearly helpful.
quotes.speaker: Keith Coleman
quotes.context: An actionable approach to setting thresholds: calibrate algorithmic cutoffs empirically via human evaluation until a clear boundary emerges.

quotes.topic_title: Thresholds, conservatism, and note quality controls
quotes.text: So we'd rather not show a note that maybe good, but we didn't have enough signal on than the other way around.
quotes.speaker: Jay Baxter
quotes.context: A conservative product principle that prioritizes trust: default to withholding when confidence is low rather than risking a wrong display.

quotes.topic_title: How many notes show and handling polarized raters
quotes.text: We probably show about 8% of notes that get proposed. It's been between, let's say, 7% and 10% or 11%, something like that over time.
quotes.speaker: Keith Coleman
quotes.context: A concrete benchmark for how selective the system is, useful for setting expectations and designing for high precision over high recall.

quotes.topic_title: How many notes show and handling polarized raters
quotes.text: We want to show a note when it's going to be helpful, when it's not going to appear biased and undermine trust in the system.
quotes.speaker: Keith Coleman
quotes.context: A practical decision rule: optimize for perceived neutrality/trustworthiness, not just factual correctness.

quotes.topic_title: How many notes show and handling polarized raters
quotes.text: And as Jay was saying, we view the worst possible mistake as showing a bad note because that's going to undermine trust and the trust is why people like the product.
quotes.speaker: Keith Coleman
quotes.context: A counterintuitive product-quality philosophy: false positives are more damaging than false negatives in trust-based systems.

quotes.topic_title: How many notes show and handling polarized raters
quotes.text: So if you consistently rate notes in a way that is counter to the bridging-based consensus, then we will stop counting your ratings.
quotes.speaker: Jay Baxter
quotes.context: An actionable mechanism for handling low-quality or adversarial participation: downweight/ignore raters who diverge from cross-group consensus.

quotes.topic_title: How many notes show and handling polarized raters
quotes.text: But our view is it's actually we want to have all of humanity here. Because if we have all of humanity, we then have the data to understand what notes will be helpful to actual humanity.
quotes.speaker: Keith Coleman
quotes.context: A memorable participation model: maximize viewpoint diversity to better predict what will be broadly helpful, rather than gatekeeping who can contribute.

quotes.topic_title: Volunteer motivation and real-world influence
quotes.text: Yeah. It's totally based on intrinsic motivation and we think that's a great reason to be doing it.
quotes.speaker: Keith Coleman
quotes.context: Highlights a practical motivation model for volunteer-driven systems: optimize for intrinsic motivation rather than pay.

quotes.topic_title: Volunteer motivation and real-world influence
quotes.text: So when we first launched US-wide, this was like in 2022, a note appeared on a White House tweet and the White House deleted the tweet and reissued an updated statement.
quotes.speaker: Keith Coleman
quotes.context: Concrete example showing real-world influence of Community Notes and how product mechanisms can change institutional behavior.

quotes.topic_title: Volunteer motivation and real-world influence
quotes.text: Imagine being the person who wrote that. You probably have 12 followers. Your posts probably get a couple likes. And here, you just put a note on the White House and they changed their public talking points based on what you did.
quotes.speaker: Keith Coleman
quotes.context: Counterintuitive observation that small accounts can drive outsized impact when credibility is decoupled from follower count.

quotes.topic_title: Volunteer motivation and real-world influence
quotes.text: Working on this product has made me realize just how many things I used to trust by default, that now I look at more skeptically.
quotes.speaker: Keith Coleman
quotes.context: Actionable mindset shift for practitioners: treat default trust as a bias and build habits/systems that encourage skepticism and verification.

quotes.topic_title: Behavioral impact: engagement drops and deletions
quotes.text: We saw more like 30 to 40% engagement rate drops for likes and reposts in A-B tests we were ran when showing a post with or without a note, which is just crazy big.
quotes.speaker: Jay Baxter
quotes.context: Quantifies the unusually large causal impact (via A/B testing) of adding a note on direct engagement behaviors.

quotes.topic_title: Behavioral impact: engagement drops and deletions
quotes.text: If you capture the overall network effect of how post spread less by that person's repost, basically if you look top line with a difference in differences approach, multiple different external research groups have both found consistently that there's a 50 or 60% drop in total reposts, which is just nuts after a note is applied.
quotes.speaker: Jay Baxter
quotes.context: Offers a measurement methodology (difference-in-differences) and a top-line outcome metric for network-level spread reduction.

quotes.topic_title: Behavioral impact: engagement drops and deletions
quotes.text: Yeah, the notes just totally take the wind out these stories. The thing will be going viral, note appears, resharing drops 50 to 60%, and that's it. At 50 to 60% per generation, the virality quickly goes to zero.
quotes.speaker: Keith Coleman
quotes.context: Provides a memorable mental model (“per generation” decay) for how interventions compound through sharing cascades.

quotes.topic_title: Behavioral impact: engagement drops and deletions
quotes.text: By the way, I have very mixed feelings about this next one, but authors become 80% more likely to decrease, sorry, to delete their post after they get noted, which okay, that's great, because less misinfo out there, but I'm pan about, because those are usually the best notes.
quotes.speaker: Jay Baxter
quotes.context: Highlights a counterintuitive tradeoff: the strongest corrections may reduce future learning if they trigger deletions.

quotes.topic_title: Origin story: why Keith started the project
quotes.text: As a user, it was obvious that I could get good information there, but it was also obvious that there was questionable information floating around.
quotes.speaker: Keith Coleman
quotes.context: Highlights a practical product lens: start from firsthand user observation of both value and failure modes in an information system.

quotes.topic_title: Origin story: why Keith started the project
quotes.text: It was obvious nothing was working. Nothing could handle the scale of the problem, nothing could handle the speed, and a lot of people just didn't trust the existing approaches.
quotes.speaker: Keith Coleman
quotes.context: A clear diagnostic for solution design: any approach must address scale, speed, and legitimacy/trust—not just accuracy.

quotes.topic_title: Origin story: why Keith started the project
quotes.text: The existing approaches were either fact-checkers or internal trust and safety teams making decisions about what was or was not misleading. A lot of people just didn't want or trust that to be the way this was decided, which is very reasonable.
quotes.speaker: Keith Coleman
quotes.context: Counterintuitive takeaway: even “correct” centralized moderation can fail if users don’t accept the decision-making authority.

quotes.topic_title: Origin story: why Keith started the project
quotes.text: I'm at this company where you can make a difference on this problem, why not go and try some crazy ideas and see if one of them might work?
quotes.speaker: Keith Coleman
quotes.context: Actionable career/product advice: when positioned close to leverage, carve out space to run high-upside experiments on the hardest problem.

quotes.topic_title: Origin story: why Keith started the project
quotes.text: It started with just reading any research I could on the problem and existing solutions. What was or was not working, what were the issues, and then into prototyping.
quotes.speaker: Keith Coleman
quotes.context: A replicable methodology: begin with broad research on prior art and failure modes, then rapidly prototype.

quotes.topic_title: Twitter era context and renaming Birdwatch to Community Notes
quotes.text: Jack had relatively recently come back as CEO to turn the company around, and just to give you a sense of the state of the company, something like a third of employees were leaving every year. Just imagine a third of your team gone every year.
quotes.speaker: Keith Coleman
quotes.context: A concrete retention metric that illustrates how severe organizational churn can be during a turnaround.

quotes.topic_title: Twitter era context and renaming Birdwatch to Community Notes
quotes.text: The stock was in the toilet, the product was not really growing, so Jack was working on a turnaround and Kayvon was there already.
quotes.speaker: Keith Coleman
quotes.context: A succinct snapshot of the business + product signals that typically trigger (and define) a turnaround context.

quotes.topic_title: Twitter era context and renaming Birdwatch to Community Notes
quotes.text: Soon after the exhibition, he DM'd me and he was like, "Hey, this Community Notes thing is awesome," and I was like, "I'm glad you like it, let's talk," so we talked the next day and he kept referring to it as "This Community Notes thing."
quotes.speaker: Keith Coleman
quotes.context: Shows a practical pattern: validate executive enthusiasm quickly and use their language to align on the product narrative.

quotes.topic_title: Twitter era context and renaming Birdwatch to Community Notes
quotes.text: The very first figma mockup I made depicting this thing was called "Community Notes." I don't know why, it just felt really natural, so that's the first prototype we had tested.
quotes.speaker: Keith Coleman
quotes.context: Highlights an iterative methodology: early prototypes and naming can reveal the most intuitive framing before later rebrands complicate it.

quotes.topic_title: Twitter era context and renaming Birdwatch to Community Notes
quotes.text: I think it is a very understandable, intuitive name, and I think it has served the product really well.
quotes.speaker: Keith Coleman
quotes.context: A product lesson that descriptive naming can materially improve comprehension and adoption.

quotes.topic_title: Small-team leadership, impact, and the Thermal model
quotes.text: I think there's one myth that can get in people's ways. The idea that the more people you manage or the larger your scope is, the more impact you have. I definitely do not think that is true.
quotes.speaker: Keith Coleman
quotes.context: Contrarian career/leadership insight that challenges the default assumption that bigger org scope equals bigger impact.

quotes.topic_title: Small-team leadership, impact, and the Thermal model
quotes.text: If I had stayed running a large consumer PM team, what would I have produced? 16 more pages of OKRs? I don't know, a bunch of documents? I think building Community Notes has had way bigger impact on the world.
quotes.speaker: Keith Coleman
quotes.context: Concrete example of choosing hands-on building over management track to maximize real-world impact.

quotes.topic_title: Small-team leadership, impact, and the Thermal model
quotes.text: They could run through their own process, they would have one clear owner. The team would be entirely dedicated to that project and we would just repeatedly make funding decisions as to whether to continue the effort.
quotes.speaker: Keith Coleman
quotes.context: Core “Thermal” operating model: isolated team, single owner, full dedication, and ongoing funding checkpoints.

quotes.topic_title: Small-team leadership, impact, and the Thermal model
quotes.text: Another was 100% focus, so everyone on the project is expected to be totally focused on it.
quotes.speaker: Keith Coleman
quotes.context: Actionable team-design principle that removes context switching to preserve momentum and throughput.

quotes.topic_title: Small-team leadership, impact, and the Thermal model
quotes.text: When we were 100% focused, we talk in the morning, it's like, "Hey, Jay. Why don't we try this thing in the algorithm?" He's like, "Yeah." Then that afternoon or the next day, we're looking at results.
quotes.speaker: Keith Coleman
quotes.context: Specific iteration-speed example showing how focus and tight loops translate into rapid experimentation.

quotes.topic_title: Early engineering approach and algorithm evolution setup
quotes.text: It started with just me and then, when we decided to build the thing, we figured we needed about five. We wanted it to be as small as we possibly could.
quotes.speaker: Keith Coleman
quotes.context: A concrete example of deliberately sizing an early team to the minimum viable cross-functional set.

quotes.topic_title: Early engineering approach and algorithm evolution setup
quotes.text: The actual first algorithm that I put into production was very focused on anti-manipulation. It was this page rank variant, but it didn't solve the problem of bias, basically.
quotes.speaker: Jay Baxter
quotes.context: Shows an iterative approach where an initial anti-manipulation solution failed on bias, prompting a rethink of the objective.

quotes.topic_title: Early engineering approach and algorithm evolution setup
quotes.text: If there are more users on one side, a page rank type graph algorithm can actually amplify those biases.
quotes.speaker: Jay Baxter
quotes.context: A counterintuitive warning that common graph-ranking methods can worsen imbalance when the underlying population is skewed.

quotes.topic_title: Early engineering approach and algorithm evolution setup
quotes.text: I think, after building that prototype and getting data from that, it was clear that the bridging-based algorithm was going to be the way that we needed to solve it, and at that point, basically I set up a bake-off. Kind of a Kaggle competition or something. That was the key time where it was really important to pull in other engineers.
quotes.speaker: Jay Baxter
quotes.context: A practical methodology: use prototype data to choose direction, then run an internal competition to accelerate algorithm improvement with more engineers.
